It is often served cold and is a refreshing starter or side dish, emphasizing the natural sea flavor and crispness of the seaweed.	<>	Seaweed Salad (Kombu Seaweed Salad): Made with green and black kelp, garnished with a thin carrot strip, served cold, and often seasoned with soy sauce or sesame oil. It's typically prepared by soaking and slightly boiling the seaweed, then cooling it and adding dressing.	<>	Seaweed salad features vibrant green and orange strands of kelp and carrot, seasoned with sesame oil and sesame seeds, served cold in a clear bowl with chopsticks on the side.	<>	Seaweed salad is made with vibrant green seaweed, a hint of orange carrot for color contrast, and a glossy glaze, often lightly steamed or blanched to retain freshness and texture.
/food-101/images/seaweed_salad/1336879.jpg			The seaweed salad is a vibrant green dish featuring finely shredded seaweed and garnished with sesame seeds, served in a white, scalloped bowl. It is typically prepared by blanching or boiling seaweed and then cooling it before tossing with a light dressing.	<>	Seaweed salad consists of steamed or blanched seaweed, often mixed with sesame seeds, sesame oil, and a bit of vinegar, creating a vibrant green texture and glossy appearance.	<>	Seaweed Salad is a vibrant green, finely chopped seaweed in a white bowl, seasoned with sesame seeds and soy sauce, making it a refreshing and visually appealing dish.	<>	Seaweed Salad (Gyokujin): made from seaweed, sesame seeds, and possibly vinegar or soy sauce, it is typically lightly seasoned and served cold, often with a slightly chewy texture and a fresh, slightly salty flavor, typically presented in a white bowl.	<>	The seaweed salad is made with vibrant green seaweed, garnished with sesame seeds, and served in a white bowl with a flower-like shape. It appears fresh and is likely cold, with a slight sheen from a light dressing.
